Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Analyzing the Relationship Between Livestock Grazing and Locust Activity in Inner Mongolia, China
Award.AbstractNarration:
Locusts are a devastating problem in many regions of the world with the risk potential highest for farmers and ranchers. This research seeks to quantify the impact of a locust infestation on livestock markets in Inner Mongolia, China. Locusts at high densities are known to compete with livestock for food, but it is important to also understand how this impacts meat production and prices. Furthermore, recent ecological study has demonstrated that locust density decreases when the number of animals grazed on a given area is reduced. Using data collected in collaboration with Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, this research will quantify the expected financial loss farmers will experience from locusts in this region.

Using data on meat prices and yields, we calculate the own-price and cross-price elasticities of demand and supply for sheep, goats and other livestock produced in Inner Mongolia at the farm and retail level. These values are used to build an equilibrium displacement model, which calculates how changes in yield due to a production shock impact price and supply at the farm and retail level. We will examine two scenarios: one where the representative farmer grazes at a high intensity and one where the representative farmer grazes at a moderate intensity. The results of this model will be used to examine the expected financial loss a farmer will experience due to locusts in both scenarios which will be used to determine whether or not it is in the farmer?s best interests to reduce grazing intensity as a mitigation method. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the collection and analysis of data from livestock producers in Inner Mongolia, China. These producers raise livestock on grassland pasture, which has become degraded in recent years due to overgrazing. As pasture is degraded, conditions arise that are favored by Mongolian locust swarms. The combination of long-term degradation and locust activity can be devastating to these livestock producers.  

We collected financial and personal information from producers to understand their economic circumstances and examine why they are motivated to overgraze given the risks associated with doing so. Using livestock and livestock product selling prices and farm costs, we constructed typical farm budgets. We found that the typical livestock herder in this region is extremely vulnerable to grass loss. We also found that these herders are earning positive profits only because they are producing more animals than is recommended for land management. 

We found that current property rights and political policies, coupled with short-term planning, are the key drivers behind their behavior. We recommend incentive-based programs to encourage lower stocking rates and better long-term planning. 

These results have been presented at multiple conferences and have been written in two journal articles, one of which is under review and one of which is soon to be submitted.
